pullRequest.body:
We add a text-based check to the `lint-style` script, that every file either (transitively) imports Mathlib.Init, or is (transitively) imported by it.

----------

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [2b000b5132](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/18281/commits/2b000b51323a7829c43e73f5cb572d0f8af32f52)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

`+ checkInitImports`
`+ findImports`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

Right now the module doc of Mathlib.Init says something like "this file is imported by virtually every file in Mathlib". If we add this linter, perhaps we should update that text and also mention that it's enforced by litner.
Good point, updated the doc-string!
Thanks for the comments; I have updated the code accordingly.
I realised that this PR presumably makes `init-creation.sh` obsolete: I'd leave removing that for a follow-up PR.

I am suddenly a bit confused about this "duplication" of `Init` file.

It seems that before `Mathlib.Init` was the root file.

However, now everything that is imported by `Mathlib.Init` imports the header linter (except for the header linter itself).

Would it make more sense to check that every file in `Mathlib` either is the file with the header linter, or has a `Mathlib` import?

This is also a comment about #18275, right?
You're right - this effectively establishes the `Header` linter as a file that is "more root" that `Mathlib.Init`. (Hopefully, only authors of syntax linters need to become aware of this fact.) I agree that this might be slightly unelegant from a theoretical perspective. I like the benefit of checking every file for copyright headers (and that seems fitting as the "most root" check of all, given that it - very unlikely has, but theoretically remotely in principle could - have legal implications, unlike any style linter).
That said, I don't care very strongly about this: if you find this confusing and less helpful, I'm happy to remove this "pre-root" file.

Taking a step back:
- I would like to remove the Python copyright linter. It's just nicer to have infrastructure written in Lean, and as syntax linters.
- Currently, the header linter doesn't cover the imports of Mathlib.Init - so there is a small gap. You were not really happy with the gap (I agree with this).
- Importing the header linter closes the above gap, by making sure the copyright is checked everywhere.

I am happy to un-import the header linter, but that means a previous concern of yours in addressed less. What do you think which of these options do you prefer?



I *would* like to, however, land this check for importing `Mathlib.Init`. The dependent PRs show this is easy to get wrong; I personally like this solution as it is more lightweight that `init-creation.sh`. (That script was great for creating the Init file! But for checking, a different mechanism suffices.)

Yes, my comment refers to the combination of this PR and #18275.

I am fine with the header linter being the *de facto* `Init` file, while maintaining an "official" stance that `Mathlib.Init` is the root.

Taking this for granted, shouldn't the style linter in this file then check that every file that is not the header linter imports a file that starts with `Mathlib`?  That should simplify the script in this PR, right?

That is a very good point; you are right: if every file except the `Header` linter itself imports something in mathlib, since imports are acyclic, they must transitively import the Header linter.

This does not prevent importing the header linter instead of Mathlib.Init --- so I tend to leave the check "if you're importing the header linter directly, you're imported in Mathlib.Init" in place. WDYT?

(I'm fixing the merge conflict right now.)
Merge conflict is fixed, and I rewrote the logic to be closer to what you propose. Thanks for the idea!

Code is updated now. The new import parsing is indeed much more robust, thanks for pointing me to it.

I hit one surprising detail: `parseImports'` always returns an extra module `Init`, in addition to the results I'd expect. Is this related to the Lean prelude, or something? For now, I added a comment and am manually removing this.
In terms of landing this: this PR contains #18275, so it probably makes sense to land that one first. Marking as blocked accordingly, but the logic here can be reviewed independently.

> I hit one surprising detail: `parseImports'` always returns an extra module `Init`, in addition to the results I'd expect. Is this related to the Lean prelude, or something? For now, I added a comment and am manually removing this.

`Init` (not `Mathlib.Init`!) is `prelude` and, by default, importing nothing means importing `Init` only.  It is similar to `simp only` that uses only a couple of default lemmas.
Thanks for explaining - I have clarified the comment now, and made `findImports` not return `Init`.
I just merged master again. Assuming CI passes, is there anything left you would like to see?
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by adomani.

Apart from the (optional) style suggestions, I am happy with this version, thanks!

maintainer delegate
Thanks!  Just a few minor remarks.

This is looking good!  I like the "dual root": everything imports `Header`, but everything that is not imported by `Init`, should import `Init`.

If actually parsing the imports is viable, that would make the script much more robust, I think.

Apart from the (optional) style suggestions, I am happy with this version, thanks!

maintainer delegate

```suggestion
This file defines the `lint-style` executable which runs all text-based style linters.
```
this correction probably cannot be successfully applied, since it is outside of the modified lines.

If the linter is ran on a computer with path-separator different from `/`. then the path `Mathlib/Init.lean` would not be recognized, right?

I also wonder about the `lean` extension in `allModules`.

Good catch! Should somebody write a linter against scripts doing manual path manipulation like this? At least for mathlib scripts, gradually forcing less use of duct tape could be useful :-)

`allModules` parses `Mathlib.lean` --- lines in it look like `import Mathlib.Algebra.Algebra.Pi`, so `allModules` contains entries like `Mathlib.Algebra.Algebra.Pi`, i.e. is a list of module names. Does that answer your question?

I was more wondering about `Mathlib.lean` and whether there might be some system-dependent issue in using the extension "manually" instead of going via some `addExtension` API.  It looks fine as is, though.

```suggestion
    return true
```
I think that you should be returning a `Bool`, not a `Prop`, right?

Similar comment for the later return values.
Oh yes! Fixed.
Wasn't it more correct with "virtually"?  There are still some mathlib files that do not import `Mathlib.Init`, after all.
I don't feel strongly about this; reverted to the previous phrasing.
Doesn't `DeclarationNames` already import `Header`?  This is redundant (though maybe it is not necessary to trim transitive imports here).
Indeed, good spot - this is superfluous now.
Have you tried to use [docs#Lean.parseImports'](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Lean/Elab/ParseImportsFast.html#Lean.parseImports')?  It promises to be fast...
I hadn't realized that existed - this is indeed nicer. I've changed the code to use it, here and further below.
Testing reveals that this function always seems to add a spurious module `Init`. Is this related to the Lean prelude? Anyway, this is easy to remove manually.

```suggestion
    let path := mkFilePath (module.components.map toString) |>.addExtension "lean"
```
This may also work.

```suggestion
    -- This file is transitively imported by `Mathlib.Init`.
```

pullRequest.title: feat: check that every file imports Mathlib.Init

Thanks!  Just a few minor remarks.
Thanks for the comments; I have updated the code accordingly.

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore: import the `header` linter in all files imported in Mathlib.Init

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore(scripts): require all scripts to be documented in the README

nodes.body: Merge conflict is fixed, and I rewrote the logic to be closer to what you propose. Thanks for the idea!

This is looking good!  I like the "dual root": everything imports `Header`, but everything that is not imported by `Init`, should import `Init`.

If actually parsing the imports is viable, that would make the script much more robust, I think.

Code is updated now. The new import parsing is indeed much more robust, thanks for pointing me to it.

I hit one surprising detail: `parseImports'` always returns an extra module `Init`, in addition to the results I'd expect. Is this related to the Lean prelude, or something? For now, I added a comment and am manually removing this.
In terms of landing this: this PR contains #18275, so it probably makes sense to land that one first. Marking as blocked accordingly, but the logic here can be reviewed independently.

> I hit one surprising detail: `parseImports'` always returns an extra module `Init`, in addition to the results I'd expect. Is this related to the Lean prelude, or something? For now, I added a comment and am manually removing this.

`Init` (not `Mathlib.Init`!) is `prelude` and, by default, importing nothing means importing `Init` only.  It is similar to `simp only` that uses only a couple of default lemmas.

I just merged master again. Assuming CI passes, is there anything left you would like to see?

Apart from the (optional) style suggestions, I am happy with this version, thanks!
